HEADLINE: Legalize or Bust 

BYLINE: By David M. Sperling. 
David M. Sperling is an immigration lawyer.

DATELINE: Huntington Station 

 BODY:
AS the national debate over illegal immigration reaches a fever pitch, it may come as a surprise to learn that legalization of undocumented immigrants from Latin America has been under way on Long Island for more than 15 years.
 Special immigration programs starting in 1991 have provided work permits and green cards to tens of thousands of Salvadorans, Guatemalans and Hondurans on Long Island. Their integration into the region's economy provides a glimpse of how legalization could transform the nation.
The greater metropolitan area is unusual because its immigrant population is overwhelmingly Central American, not Mexican. Unlike Mexicans, Central Americans have been the beneficiaries of some of the country's most generous immigration policies. 
 Refugees fleeing guerrilla wars and natural catastrophes in El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras streamed onto Long Island starting in the 1980's. After applying for political asylum or temporary protected status, they were able to obtain work permits, Social Security cards and driver's licenses.
 Salvadorans -- by far the largest immigrant group on Long Island -- have been the beneficiaries of two separate protected-status programs, first in 1991 and again in 2001 after devastating earthquakes in their homeland. 
 The latest program, recently extended for another year, has alone resulted in the legalization, albeit temporary, of more than 25,000 Salvadorans living on Long Island. Hondurans living in the United States since 1998 were also eligible for temporary protected status after Hurricane Mitch, and their status has recently been extended to July 2007.
 A 1997 law called the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act, has led to legal permanent resident status for more than 12,000 Salvadorans and Guatemalans on Long Island. Thousands more Hispanic immigrants have obtained green cards through work, marriage and family relationships.
 When immigrants attain legal status, everything changes. 
 Emerging from the shadowy underworld of the estimated 125,000 illegal immigrants on Long Island, legal immigrants have become an integral part of the region's economy. With their coveted work permits and Social Security numbers, they get jobs on the company payroll or start their own businesses, all the while paying taxes and contributing to Social Security. 
 Instead of sending all their money back home, they are investing in their communities, buying houses and revitalizing decaying neighborhoods in communities like Bay Shore, Brentwood, Hempstead, Huntington Station and Patchogue.
 The negative images that many people have about illegal immigrants would be erased by a legalization program like the compromise measure under consideration in the Senate. That plan would divide undocumented immigrants into three categories, providing a route to citizenship for law-abiding, tax-paying workers who speak English and have been in the United States for at least five years. 
 In many respects, the first category is similar to the programs under which Salvadorans and Guatemalans obtained legal permanent resident status. Those Salvadorans and Guatemalans were required to show continuous residence for seven years, ''good moral character'' -- a term of art that has helped root out criminals by checking for misdemeanors and felonies -- and proof of tax payments. Every applicant had to appear before an immigration official at the New York Asylum Office in Rosedale, Queens. As I know from representing hundreds of these applicants, approval rates are high, but the program is certainly not an amnesty.
 Temporary protected status is analogous to the second category, for those undocumented immigrants who have been in the United States for two to five years. These immigrants would qualify as guest workers but would have to leave and re-enter the country to retain that status. They also would be required to demonstrate good moral character.
 Of course, there are those undocumented immigrants who do not qualify for legalization -- the third category in the Senate plan. These immigrants are unlikely to leave voluntarily and no president would order mass deportations. Desperate migrants will always find a way to sneak in, no matter how many billions of dollars are allocated to border security. 
 But at least it would be the first step to repair a system that simply no longer works. If Long Island's experience is any guide, the best solution is legalization.

HEADLINE: Quinnipiac Plans More Dorms, to Hamden's Relief 

BYLINE: By C. J. HUGHES

 BODY:
ONE lone building was enough to house Quinnipiac University, then a tiny commuter school known as the Connecticut College of Commerce, when it opened in Hamden in 1929.
 Now, the school takes up half the town, or so it seems to many neighbors, who complain that the school's surging growth is destroying Hamden's small-town New England character. Quinnipiac, which has 17 graduate programs, a well-known polling service and nationally ranked sports teams, is now sprawled across 500 acres on two campuses.
More specifically, these neighbors criticize Quinnipiac for not building enough dorms for its students, forcing about 2,000 of its 5,000 undergraduate students to bunk off-campus, which brings noise and clutter, they said, to residential neighborhoods used to cleanliness and quiet. 
 ''It's not the students in the housing, it's the student housing that doesn't belong,'' said Lester Faiman, a 60-year resident of the Mount Carmel section of Hamden, which includes the school. 
 Mr. Faiman also serves as a co-president of Concerned Citizens for Hamden Neighborhoods, a 100-member group that formed last November to oppose Quinnipiac's expansion plans. 
 ''It's a very poor situation that has grown beyond acceptable,'' Mr. Faiman said.
 Quinnipiac administrators announced at a town meeting on April 18 that the school plans enough new dormitories for another 2,348 students, which would take almost all of the overflow students out of the community and put them back on campus. The university has 13 dormitories and said it will build five more in the next five years.
 That could finally address the longstanding housing shortage, which the school is acutely aware of.
 ''The primary issue here is that people in their late teens and 20's are living in a residential neighborhood,'' said Lynn Bushnell, a school spokeswoman. ''If you're a family with young children, you're up early and in bed early, and that's not the lifestyle of a 20-year-old.''
 Many residents said they are pleased with the physical expansion to the main campus on Mount Carmel Avenue, which now features low-slung buildings and brick-lined walks, nestled at the base of Sleeping Giant State Park, a series of tree-draped ridges popular with hikers. 
 The same residents are also grateful that Quinnipiac gives back a lot to Hamden in terms of entertainment, whether arts or athletics, rock concerts or hockey games. And the school, which is Hamden's largest employer after the town itself, is clearly an economic engine.
 Yet negative effects of a small college's quick transformation into a major university are felt strongly in an area still dotted with some Colonial homes and horse farms.
 During the day, cars clog the major road, Route 10, where a traffic light can change twice before stopped cars can pass underneath. In recent years, parked cars have also lined up two or three deep on suburban lawns.
 ''Quinnipiac for all its glory and wonder and greatness has definitely sprawled,'''' said Joseph Pepe, an archivist for the Hamden Historical Society and 27-year Hamden resident. ''That has created problems.''
 A solution for decreasing the number of students who live in Quinnipiac's surrounding neighborhoods that is favored by many residents is simply to enforce existing laws.
 One of them is a zoning regulation, approved in 2001, that represents an earlier effort to crack down on the numbers of students sharing off-campus houses. 
 The regulation stipulates that an absentee landlord who wants to rent to a student must get a special permit from the town's planning and zoning office. Even with a permit, no more than four students can live in a one-family home, unless the students are related. 
 Mayor Craig Henrici said his promise to enforce this regulation helped propel him to victory in Hamden's mayoral election last fall. 
 Mr. Henrici, who is a Democrat, appointed a new town planner and filled two zoning enforcement positions that had been empty. 
 And the new hires got right to work. Between Mr. Henrici's election in November and April, the zoning officers issued 15 notices of violation, 2 cease-and-desist orders and a fine, almost all having to do with student overcrowding, according to preliminary figures from Hamden's planning and zoning office.
 But cracking down on all students who are living in illegal conditions may be a formidable task. 
 Of the 400 off-campus addresses where students are known to live, only about 45 have permits allowing students, zoning officials said. Although many of the 400 addresses are apartment buildings, which don't need permits, zoning officials said many others are one-family homes that are renting to students without a permit. Also, some students both own and live in their units, so they don't need permits.
 Further complicating matters is tracking down landlords, some of whom live out of state. Other landlords buy homes through trusts, so it can be difficult to determine who owns the property.
 Still, in what zoning officials said was a possible sign of improving town-university relations, Quinnipiac has started sharing its records of known student off-campus addresses with town officials. That, plus the announcement about the new dorms, is heartening to the mayor.
 ''Change won't be immediate, and we realize that it's very unlikely that 100 percent of the student body will ever want to live on campus,'' Mr. Henrici said. ''But we can deal with 5 percent who don't.''
 Yet even some landlords who said that they play by the rules said the deck is stacked against them in the community, because the neighbors are so soured.
 ''I don't understand these people who complain, not one of them,'' said Ari Gorfain, president of the Hamden-based AMG Property Management, who said that all of his houses are properly permitted.
 He said he owned ''a dozen'' homes, not wanting to be specific because of concerns that residents would be upset with him for renting to so many students. 
 ''If they were smart, the neighbors would turn this into a positive and sell their homes,'' said Mr. Gorfain, who is also a local DJ and co-owner of two New Haven night clubs. ''They could probably get four times what they paid.''
 For its part, Quinnipiac promises on-campus housing for undergraduates for their first three years. As seniors, students are on their own. (Quinnipiac also plays the role of off-campus landlord, offering 30 homes for students.)
 But some students complain that the guaranteed housing is far from desirable. 
 Leah Silverstone, a sophomore from Melrose, Mass., said Quinnipiac, where undergraduate tuition, including room and board, costs $36,980 a year, sometimes packs 12 people into suites designed for 8.
 As a result, she is looking to live in an apartment near the campus, in a neighborhood popular with students.
 ''When I went away to college, I didn't realize it was going to be like this,'' Ms. Silverstone said. ''It's extremely frustrating.''
 When the school gets new dorms, most of them are planned for the Sherman Avenue campus, part of a $200 million five-year expansion plan, which also calls for a student center and new parking lots.
 The 250-acre property, which was bought in pieces by the university beginning in 1997, is already home to a new hockey and basketball arena, which is under construction but whose gleaming roof is visible from the top of Sleeping Giant.
 Whether or not Quinnipiac will continue to leave its mark on the land with more buildings is somewhat unclear. 
 The school has refused to cap its enrollment, but promises, as part of its expansion plan, to have a bed on campus for every undergraduate student. ''We will not grow at the undergraduate level unless we have enough residences to meet that growth,'' said Ms. Bushnell, the school spokeswoman.
 Yet some neighbors remained skeptical.
 ''The new dorms are a great undertaking, a big enterprise, but there are some big wild cards in there,'' said Joanne Iacobellis, a 40-year Hamden resident who is president of the Kenwood Valley Neighborhood Association.
 Ms. Iacobellis also serves as co-president of Concerned Citizens for Hamden Neighborhoods.
 ''We're hopeful but cautious,'' she said, ''because we're not going to have any real answers for a couple years.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Hamden residents, left, after a town meeting at which Quinnipiac announced its expansion, which includes five new dormitories on campus, above. (Photographs by Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Border Arrests Rise as U.S. Debates Immigration Issue

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO 

 BODY:
Outside a shelter for migrants in the teeming Mexican city of Tijuana, Jesus Lugo Diaz clutched a creased paper with names and numbers of people in the United States scrawled over it -- and clung to the hope of sneaking across the border.
 It would be his fifth try.
''One way or the other you're going to cross,'' Mr. Diaz, 36, said as he waited for the shelter to open and offer him a bed and food for the night, a few days after the United States Border Patrol had last caught him and sent him back.
 Here on the American side, a Border Patrol agent, Richard Kite, surveyed an array of fences, stadium lights and sensors. Mr. Kite kept a wary eye on several men loitering just across the border, singling out one perched atop a billboard. 
 ''He's probably a spotter,'' Mr. Kite said.
 The cat-and-mouse game along the 1,900-mile border with Mexico proceeds as it always has, even as the national debate over revamping immigration laws intensifies. The chanting in the streets of America's big cities and the arguing in the halls of Congress serve mostly as background noise.
 The ebb and flow of arrests also goes on, with the Border Patrol watching a dip in central Arizona and a spike in San Diego and other developed areas for signs of shifting smuggling patterns. 
 Some suggest that a Senate proposal to adopt a guest worker program, possibly leading to legal residency and citizenship for many of the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States, might be inspiring more people to try a crossing. Others say the larger numbers indicate nothing more than stepped up enforcement or even a statistical aberration. Nobody really knows. 
 The peaks and valleys of arrests over the years reflect a variety of social, economic and political influences, including the pull of jobs and family here, a lack of opportunity on the other side, or even the weather. 
 What is certain is the United States keeps building up its border defenses, with more planned this year, including adding 1,500 agents and spending some $35 million in Arizona alone on surveillance equipment.
 People still keep trying to get in, tucked under the dashboards of cars, tunneling under the fences -- more than a dozen passages have been found this year -- throwing bicycles over the barriers and pedaling away like weekend enthusiasts, crawling through brush, and walking, walking and walking -- sometimes dying in the desert. 
 ''They are ingenious sometimes,'' Mr. Kite said.
 Fresh off a four-day bus ride from Leon, Mexico, Roberto Estrada, 43, toted a small plastic grocery bag with his belongings and planned to bed down the night before making contact with a smuggler. He said he had heard nothing about the immigration debate in the United States and was simply itching for work, maybe in a restaurant, but he would not get picky.
 ''I'll take whatever job,'' Mr. Estrada said.
 After a peak of 1,676,438 arrests in 2000, apprehensions dropped, but they have drifted upward again to 1,189,067 in 2005 from 931,557 in 2003.
 While the Border Patrol attributes the increase to the build up of security, scholars who study the border said it was more likely that migration was rebounding from an economic slump after the Sept. 11 attacks and years of diminished back-and-forth crossings by repeat crossers. 
 In the San Diego sector, which includes some of the Border Patrol's heaviest fortifications, federal agents have apprehended 90,843 people since October, a 33 percent increase over the same period a year before.
 Along the busiest stretch for crossings, a 1,000-mile stretch from San Diego to the Texas state line, there have been 699,609 arrests over the same period, a 6 percent increase. 
 But arrest figures fluctuate, so the Border Patrol cannot declare a trend. As a rule of thumb, the agency estimates that for every person arrested two or three get through. But because of repeat arrests the number of apprehensions does not necessarily reflect the actual number of people trying to cross. 
 Still, people familiar with the border crossings, including the head of the union representing the border agents, suggest that the crossing attempts are growing, with some of those inspired by the prospect of a guest worker program.
 ''I think we are starting to see the early stage of a rush to take advantage of what is perceived to be a shift in immigration policy,'' said T. J. Bonner, president of the union, the National Border Patrol Council.
 Mr. Bonner said some of the people arrested had told agents that they believed Congress had approved a guest worker program that would make their presence in the United States legal. 
 Mario Martinez, a spokesman for the Border Patrol in Washington, did not dismiss the guest worker program as a factor in the rising numbers of crossing efforts, but he said other influences, like jobs and reuniting with family, could also account for the increase. 
 Wayne A. Cornelius, director of the Center for Comparative Immigration Studies at the University of California, San Diego, said researchers there recently surveyed prospective migrants from the Yucatan Peninsula. They found that 60 percent of them had heard of the guest worker debate and that 30 percent said it would make them more likely to go the United States if it was approved. Only one who had already made the trip said the program was the main reason. 
 Operators of shelters in Mexico said they had noticed an increase in the number of people passing through, but they were also unsure of the cause. 
 The director of the Casa del Migrante shelter in Tijuana, the Rev. Luiz Kendzierski, said shelter visits had increased about 20 percent in the past year. More than anything, he said, grinding poverty in parts of Mexico and Central America and word from relatives about the ease of finding jobs in the United States have pushed most people to try crossing.
 At Casa Betania, a shelter in Mexicali, Mexico, Tomas Reyes Hernandez, the director, said he had heard only a few people mention the prospect of legalization as a reason for crossing. 
 ''Most people don't know what is going on in the United States,'' he said.
 At the Tijuana shelter, men flowed in and out, trading stories about their journey to the border and comparing notes on promising smugglers.
 More and more people use guides, known as coyotes or polleros, because of the dangers of the desert and the strengthened enforcement.
 ''It's not that hard if you're willing to pay a good smuggler,'' said a 23-year-old man deported from Los Angeles after an arrest for domestic violence. ''The hard part is getting the $2,000, $3,000 it costs for a good one. But sometimes they can get you across right here in Tijuana in the trunk or under the seat of a van.''

 Richard Kite, a Border Patrol agent, watched for illegal immigrants last month near San Diego, the site of some of the country's tightest security. (Photographs by Sandy Huffaker/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Plan to Reshape Mileage Standards Could Buoy Detroit

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6 

 BODY:
Of all the proposals that $3-a-gallon gasoline has elicited from Congress, the one that would do the least to bring down high gasoline prices might be higher fuel economy standards for cars, at least in the next 5 to 10 years, experts say.
 But it could help Detroit automakers, which might be just as much of a motivation for a change. 
Conservation advocates have called for higher mileage standards for years, but they and other car experts agree that during periods of high gasoline prices, the government standards, called Corporate Average Fuel Economy, or CAFE standards, are irrelevant, because consumers buy smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles without prompting. 
 For 2005, with a government requirement for a minimum average for cars of 27.5 miles per gallon, the preliminary estimate by the Environmental Protection Agency is that the actual average was 28.9 m.p.g.
 Falling gasoline prices illustrate the value of the standards, said Kateri Callahan, president of the Alliance to Save Energy, a nonprofit, nonpartisan group based here. 
 ''What you're doing with CAFE is saying, as a society, there's a minimum level of fuel efficiency that we think ought to be offered,'' Ms. Callahan said. ''History shows that when, and if, energy is cheap again, and people fall back into old and bad habits, you want to make sure they can act only so badly.'' 
 At that point, the standards limit the growth of oil imports and the average fuel economy of the fleet, and help with the balance of payments problem in the long term. That is what happened in this country in the 1990's, when a price war between Persian Gulf oil producers pushed the price of a barrel below $10. 
 But when CAFE standards were being introduced in the 1980's, the average fuel economy of vehicles sold exceeded government mandates for much of the period. That was partly a result of the oil price spike of 1979-1980, which still ranks as the most severe when prices are adjusted for inflation.
 The provision of the energy bill proposed by Senate Republican leaders, and endorsed last month by President Bush, does not explicitly call for higher standards. Instead, it calls for allowing the Transportation Department to restructure the CAFE rules for cars, as it recently did for trucks. 
 There is no strong indication that the Bush administration will raise the magic number significantly. And transportation officials already have the power to raise the number, without any action by Congress.
 What those officials want Congress to approve is legislation that would allow them to reorganize the standards, as they recently did for light trucks. Transportation officials say they would like to create a sliding scale for minimum fuel economy, based on ''footprint,'' or distance between the wheels. They say they are seeking this authority because of a study by the National Academy of Sciences that showed that forcing people into smaller vehicles had led to a slight increase in traffic deaths. 
 The administration wants to keep vehicle size constant but to force automakers to use materials and technologies that will improve fuel economy in whatever size vehicle is offered.
 In March, when transportation officials rewrote the truck standard, the new rules demanded only a small increase in overall mileage, although they pushed the minimum required fuel economy for some small sport utility vehicles to above the level now required for cars.
 Setting the standard vehicle by vehicle is important because existing car standards make no difference to some manufacturers. For example, for 2005, the most recent year for which statistics are available, Toyota and Honda both averaged 33.1 m.p.g., partly because they sold a lot of small cars, and they had no CAFE concerns.
 DaimlerChrysler averaged 26.6, and Ford, 26.9, and unlike Toyota and Honda, both manufacturers had to worry about technology and sales mix. If cars were judged individually, even small cars that performed poorly considering their size would have to be improved. Thus, the burden would fall for the first time on companies that make mostly smaller cars, generally imports. 
 The actual importance of these miles per gallon figures is also diluted somewhat by oddities of the testing procedure and rules that allow adjustments to the numbers. CAFE numbers are 15 percent higher than window-sticker numbers, and even the numbers on the window sticker are higher than what most drivers will achieve.
 In addition, automakers may earn a credit of up to 1.2 miles per gallon for building ''flex fuel'' vehicles that can run on something other than gasoline. Almost all of these are cars capable of burning ethanol, although most of them will never see ethanol beyond the 10 percent sometimes blended into ordinary gasoline. 
 Car makers can also carry over credits from previous years or borrow them from future years, which is why Ford is unlikely to pay penalties and DaimlerChrysler may not have to either, despite being below 27.5 miles per gallon.
 Some policy makers are counting on new CAFE standards for a different purpose, though. 
 Representative Sherwood Boehlert, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House Science Committee and a longtime advocate of higher standards, said that adopting them now would send a signal to automobile companies that investments in new tooling and technology to produce high-mileage vehicles will pay back for years to come. It will also stimulate inventors with new ideas, Mr. Boehlert said. 
 ''They will come out of the woodwork,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Hen Activist Says the War On Cages Will Go On

BYLINE: By MICHELLE YORK

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, May 5 

 BODY:
An animal-rights activist acquitted of burglary and other charges after admittedly sneaking onto a large commercial egg farm to film conditions there said his group would continue to pressure the company to stop caging hens.
 ''We'll embolden our efforts,'' said the activist, Adam C. Durand, of Rochester, who has lead a two-year protest against the egg-farming practices of the popular regional supermarket chain Wegmans.
Some 750,000 hens at the Wegmans farm in Wolcott, N.Y., are kept in wire cages, as are the vast majority of the nation's hens used for commercial egg production. The practice has an economic benefit, since farmers can house far more hens by stacking cages. Also, caged flocks tend to have a lower mortality rate, since they are less vulnerable to disease and predators. 
 But at some commercial farms, hens are sometimes packed so tightly into cages that they cannot lie down or flap their wings. ''It's among the most abusive factory-farming practices used today,'' said Paul Shapiro, a director of the Humane Society of the United States, who leads a campaign to ban the practice.
 A Wegmans spokeswoman, Jeanne Colleluori, said the film was not representative of the farm. ''The film was slanted in a very negative way,'' she said. 
 The Rochester group intended to dissuade consumers from buying eggs from farms that use cages by producing a film to show conditions at the Wegmans farm, one of the largest in the Northeast. 
 Mr. Durand, 26, admitted that he and several others crept onto the Wegmans property three times in 2004, hoping to capture the scene on video. He took video of some hens stuck in the wires and others wandering in the manure pits. 
 His film, released last year, caught the attention of national animal-activist groups, who supported his efforts. But it also came to the attention of the Wayne County district attorney, Richard Healy, who charged Mr. Durand with burglary, petty larceny and criminal trespass.
 Last week, as Mr. Durand was about to go on trial, the group Animal Rights International said it tried to place a $13,000 full-page advertisement in The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle. It included a photo of a decomposed hen still in its cage with several live hens, with the headline, ''Did Your Wegmans Egg Share a Cage With a Corpse?''
 The paper's publisher, Michael G. Kane, said it asked the group to remove the picture and to delay publication, considering that the Wegmans family patriarch, Robert Wegman, had recently died. ''It was a disgusting photo,'' Mr. Kane said.
 The group declined, and the ad never ran.
 At Mr. Durand's three-day trial, the farm production manager, Andrew Wadsworth, testified that that about eight of the farm's 80 employees are in charge of caring for the flock and regularly check the birds. 
 Mr. Durand testified in his defense and showed video images, for example, of a hen submerged up to its neck in manure. After 90 minutes of deliberations, the jury convicted Mr. Durand only of misdemeanor trespass charges.
 Later, he said he planned to eventually distribute a second film, one that includes information about his legal battles. ''The whole trial has strengthened our resolve,'' he said.
 Meanwhile, Ms. Colleluori, the Wegmans spokeswoman, said the company would rely on science, poultry experts and consumer demand, rather than pressure from activists, to decide how it runs its farms.
 ''We'll continue to do what's best for our farm, our employees and our hens,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Out of Favor, Into Power: Pataki's Vetoes Bring Choices

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 6 

 BODY:
Republicans in the State Senate are howling in their districts that Gov. George E. Pataki is blocking their plan to send property tax rebate checks out to homeowners before Election Day. 
 The powerful health lobby is running ads practically suggesting that the governor's budget vetoes of health care spending could kill babies.
And to top it all off, Mr. Pataki's approval ratings in New York are dropping sharply. 
 But, for all the heat he is taking, Mr. Pataki's budget vetoes have given him a shot of steroids just when the Legislature had written him off as the weakest of lame ducks. Now the Senate, for all its fury, needs something from Mr. Pataki. And they are the ones facing New York voters in November, not him. 
 Mr. Pataki, who will step down from office in eight months, can afford to look at a very different audience: the national Republicans he will have to win over if he decides to run for president.
 And while Mr. Pataki's budget vetoes -- and his declaration that several costly items, including the property tax rebate, were unconstitutional and void -- were met with wails in some quarters, they were met elsewhere with something that has become increasingly rare for Mr. Pataki in recent years: headlines praising him for fiscal restraint.
 So as Mr. Pataki navigates the rest of his final legislative session, he is being buffeted by competing political impulses. He can try to improve his approval ratings in New York and make friends with the Senate and with the health lobby by reopening the budget and spending more. Or he can hold out and try to salvage a reputation for fiscal conservatism that has been eroded by the near-doubling of the state budget during his three terms in office. 
 It is not necessarily an easy choice. No governor interested in higher office wants dismal poll numbers in his home state, which could prove an embarrassment. 
 A poll released this week by the Siena Research Institute found that only 38 percent of New Yorkers said they had a favorable opinion of Mr. Pataki, while 55 percent said they had an unfavorable opinion of him -- a steep drop since March. (The poll, of 620 registered New York voters, had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.)
 Republican senators -- fearful that they could lose their dwindling majority in November -- recently had a strategy session with Frank Luntz, a well-known Republican pollster, who told them that they should keep their distance from Mr. Pataki, according to several Republicans who attended the meeting.
 But Mr. Pataki, who has been criticized in recent years for increasing state spending and debt levels, seems to enjoy the praise his vetoes received in newspaper editorials from Long Island to New York City to Rochester and from fiscal monitors that have been highly critical of him in recent years, like the Citizens Budget Commission. 
 The praise may be too little, and too late, for a governor who oversaw state spending growth that exceeded inflation, but it could help Mr. Pataki try to win back some of the conservatives who are inherently skeptical of a Northeast Republican who is liberal on social issues.
 The question around the Capitol is, Is the budget done or not?
 This week the governor, and the other two men who run the state, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, and Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, all signaled some willingness to discuss some of the issues that were not addressed or resolved. But the governor contends that the budget is over for the year -- sort of.
 ''The budget is over, period, end of story,'' said David M. Catalfamo, the governor's communications director, who praised many of its items. Some senators say they believe that if they find a way to pay for the rebates -- so as not to increase future gaps -- they might still be able to get the governor to go along. The governor, after all, proposed his own property tax rebate program this year, but his plan called for sending checks only to homeowners who live in school districts that agree to limit spending their growth. The Legislature removed that requirement.
 It all goes to show one thing: The new era in Albany of passing budgets by the April 1 deadline may not be so different from the previous 20 years of late budgets. 
 One of the main criticisms of late budgets in Albany was the way other unrelated issues invariably became linked to the budget as they were held out as bargaining chips. This year, the budget was passed on time, but the uncertainty as to whether it is really done has once again led to a bargaining-chip mentality that pervaded in the past, when the budget often became one more card to play in debates over other legislation.
 Dozens of issues are being floated that could be tied to some kind of universal settlement -- in which everyone gets something -- when the session ends in June.
 Lawmakers are weighing proposals to increase the number of charter schools, a priority of Mr. Pataki's. There is talk of raising the salaries of judges, expanding the statewide DNA databank and taking more steps to combat Medicaid fraud. The halls buzz with all kinds of one-shot budget infusions that could add to a budget that none of the sides can agree on, but that is said to be $112.1 billion. All of these issues could find themselves in a megatrade.
 But one obstacle, from the Senate's point of view, is the State Assembly. The Assembly made out well in the budget, winning its preferred tax cut -- eliminating the sales tax on modest clothing purchases -- and winning a big school construction project. 
 Republicans, both in the Senate and those who work for the governor, are now wondering aloud what they can offer the Assembly to go along with their priorities. 
 For now, Mr. Pataki is showing that even if he is a lame duck, attention must be paid. And he seems to have caught the attention of the Senate Republicans, who opened the year bucking his wishes. But neither side is taking bets as to whether they reach a deal this year.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Slogan Goes From New to Stale

BYLINE: The Associated Press

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 6 

 BODY:
New Jersey officials have said the new state slogan, ''Come See for Yourself,'' would highlight the Garden State's true beauty.
 It turns out, however, that at least one other state already had that idea. 
 State tourism officials said they canned the slogan after it failed to pass legal muster because some states, including West Virginia, have used it in the past.
 ''We are proceeding without the slogan,'' Karen Wolfe, a spokeswoman for the state's Commerce, Economic Growth and Tourism Commission, was quoted as saying in The Press of Atlantic City's Saturday issue. ''We will revisit the next steps at the end of the year.'' 
 Former Gov. Richard J. Codey unveiled the slogan with great fanfare at a January news conference, just days before he left office.
 Mr. Codey, who remains State Senate president, said at the time that the state's catchphrase ''should hint at our true beauty.''
 The slogan was the top choice among 11,227 telephone and online votes cast by residents for five final entries in a statewide contest.
 But at an annual tourism conference in Cape May County more than a week ago, the slogan was absent from state promotional materials. 
 Tourism officials say West Virginia used the phrase in some previous promotions, but now uses ''West Virginia: Wild and Wonderful.''
 The slogan resulted from Mr. Codey's appeal in October for ideas after he rejected a marketing company's proposal for which the state paid about $250,000. He said that slogan, ''New Jersey: We'll Win You Over,'' was negative and reminded him of his own self-deprecating pitch when he asked girls out on dates.

HEADLINE: Quinn Alters Council Rules On Financing Pet Projects

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU

 BODY:
Every year, members of the City Council propose to empty the city's coffers by compiling a list of worthy causes and pet projects that they want financed, from studies on minority unemployment to new treatments for addictions.
 The so-called wish list has approached $1 billion in recent years, as the requests for money have stacked up, with individual council members submitting as many as 10 at a time. The list is then chopped down -- typically to $150 million or so in a good year -- during a series of closed-door meetings.
 But now the Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, has clamped down on that free-wheeling process, a move that has angered many of the 50 other council members and has created the most serious dissension in the legislative body since she was elected its leader in January. 
 For the first time, the speaker is requiring members to turn in a printed form whenever they want to create or finance a new citywide program or to increase the subsidy for an existing one. Each member will be limited to four such requests.
 Each request must be signed by nine other members to demonstrate ample support for the program, and the signers together must represent at least three of the five boroughs. Council members may sign onto only seven requests besides their own four. 
 The deadline for handing in requests is May 17. After that, the wish list will be closed until next year's budget negotiations.
 Ms. Quinn's rules have drawn complaints from many of the council members, who are accustomed to making as many requests as they want, whenever they want. In past years, members simply called the speaker or scrawled their requests on scraps of paper.
 Critics say the new rules are confusing to follow, create more paperwork and unfairly force them to choose among worthy causes. 
 ''Most of the council members do not seem pleased,'' said Councilman Charles Barron, of Brooklyn, who has been an outspoken critic of Ms. Quinn. ''Personally, I'd rather not do it because it puts the onus on us. People are running around trying to get signatures. It's getting a little crazy.''
 Under the previous speaker, Gifford Miller, the wish list had come to resemble something of a pork barrel, several council members said, as Mr. Miller and others used it as a way to show support for community groups. Also, members were often reluctant to turn down requests, for fear of alienating potential supporters.
 Councilman David I. Weprin, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said that the list had become unmanageable. ''It had gotten out of hand,'' he said. ''Anybody could propose whatever they wanted and there was no rhyme or reason.''
 In several instances, money was requested and approved for groups without the beneficiaries' consent or knowledge, council members said. That could lead to an awkward situation when a group had to either decline the money or hastily reorganize to conduct the new program, usually not without delays.
 Councilwoman Gale Brewer, of Manhattan, said that formerly, she would learn about items on the wish list only after the budget had passed. Under the new rules, she said, council members are being forced to pitch their programs to their colleagues openly and circulate forms for signatures. ''It is more transparent,'' she said. ''This year, everybody's in the same boat.''
 Many members, though they said the rules had made the budget process more cumbersome, gave the speaker credit for trying to make improvements. 
 ''I think it needs perfecting, but it's a good idea,'' said Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, of Brooklyn, who plans to request an additional $5.4 million for after-school programs for high school students. Requiring council members to do more work, he said, would ensure the list ''doesn't get silly.''
 Councilman Michael McMahon, of Staten Island, said that he wanted to request $1 million each for three new sanitation programs: to increase commercial garbage pickups in the boroughs outside Manhattan, expand public education about recycling and step up enforcement of laws on littering and disposal of dog waste. But he said he would submit only the first request, because he did not anticipate getting enough signatures for all three.
 Mr. McMahon said he was already feeling pressure from council members and community advocates to sign the forms. ''Being the sole Democrat from Staten Island kind of makes me popular,'' he said.
 Ms. Quinn said that the budget rules had been discussed in leadership meetings with council members before the forms were distributed last week, and that no one had directly complained to her. She said, however, that several members had raised questions or made suggestions, all of which she was considering.
 ''The reality of the budget is there will be moments when you say 'Yes,' and moments when you say, 'Sorry, no,' '' Ms. Quinn said. ''And we can't pretend that isn't what a budget is.''
 Councilman Leroy G. Comrie, of Queens, said the new rules would force the council members to focus on the things they care about most, rather than try to accommodate everyone. ''Most of the people were positively grumbling,'' he said. ''They're not happy to do more work, but they understand how this can be helpful.''

HEADLINE: 73*

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SOKOLOVE. 
Michael Sokolove, a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, is the author of ''The Ticket Out: Darryl Strawberry and the Boys of Crenshaw.''

 BODY:
GAME OF SHADOWS
 Barry Bonds, Balco, and the Steroids
 Scandal That Rocked Professional Sports.
 By Mark Fainaru-Wada and Lance Williams.
 Illustrated. 332 pp. Gotham Books. $26.

LOVE ME, HATE ME
 Barry Bonds and the Making of an Antihero.
 By Jeff Pearlman.
 Illustrated. 371 pp.
 HarperCollins Publishers. $25.95.
SO you want to be a sports star? Who's your daddy? DNA matters in sports, more than we often care to admit. That was one of the lessons of the recent men's N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, in which three of the five starters on the champion University of Florida team had fathers who were former professional athletes. And it is the subtext of the current scandal over steroids in baseball. Must you go to bat only with your so-called God-given talent? Or, if you come up a little short in that area and get yourself chemically enhanced, how exactly should your achievements and records be regarded?
 Barry Bonds -- baseball superstar, suspected drug cheat, possible perjurer and pariah -- is a second-generation big leaguer. His father, Bobby Bonds, was an all-star outfielder with the San Francisco Giants, his son's team since 1993, and a teammate of the great Willie Mays (Barry's godfather). 
 ''Game of Shadows,'' one of two new books on Barry Bonds, begins right at the moment he senses a perversion of the natural order, a new way for those without the right stuff to leap over the game's true thoroughbreds. In 1998, Bonds watched, seething, as Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa roared past the venerated season home-run marks of Babe Ruth and Roger Maris. McGwire was a big man who in 1998 appeared notably more massive. Sosa, a minor talent through his early career, and slightly built, looked as if someone had jabbed him with a bicycle pump and inflated him.
 Bonds was a perennial all-star, a three-time M.V.P. and a surefire future Hall of Famer -- everything, in fact, but a historic slugger. In 12 years, he had never approached 60 home runs in a season, and he did not seem -- as he did entering the 2006 season -- on a course to threaten the career statistics of Ruth and Hank Aaron. ''Bonds was astounded and aggrieved by the outpouring of hero worship for McGwire, a hitter whom he regarded as obviously inferior to himself,'' Mark Fainaru-Wada and Lance Williams write in ''Game of Shadows,'' an authoritative study of Bonds and baseball's steroids scandal.
 After the 1998 season, according to the book, Bonds began bulking up in the same way he believed McGwire had: by taking steroids, and later by adding human growth hormone to the mix. By 2001, the year he hit 73 home runs, wiping McGwire's record of 70 off the books, the once lean-muscled Bonds had bulging biceps, a thickened neck and a head that seemed to have grown a hat size or two. His former mistress told the authors that his back was pocked with acne, a telltale sign of steroid use, and that he suffered from impotence, another marker. 
 In grand jury testimony quoted in ''Game of Shadows,'' Bonds acknowledges applying a substance known as ''the clear,'' which federal investigators say was a steroid, after it was given to him by his childhood friend and personal trainer, Greg Anderson. But he testified that he believed it was flaxseed oil, which he took just to keep Anderson happy. He ''gave me some flaxseed oil, man,'' Bonds is quoted as telling the grand jury. ''It's like, 'Whatever, dude.' ''
 Fainaru-Wada and Williams, investigative reporters at The San Francisco Chronicle, have been out in front of the journalistic pack on the story of baseball's steroids scandal, and ''Game of Shadows'' shows their mastery of the subject. The book is based on secret grand jury testimony that they obtained and first published in their newspaper, on court records and on interviews with mostly named sources. The authors allege that Bonds participated in a sophisticated doping program that resulted in a late-career offensive surge unheard-of in baseball history. Over his first 13 seasons, Bonds hit a home run every 16.1 at-bats; from 1999 through 2004, he hit one every 8.5 at-bats.
 The book is economical in its character study of Bonds, which is wise because what the authors do include just confirms his well-established reputation for boorishness. Its real strength comes in the connections it makes between the baseball doping scandal and the wider culture of drugs in international sports. The nexus for this was the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative (Balco), brainchild of Victor Conte. 
 Conte is an entertaining figure, of sorts, an idea-a-minute man and huckster par excellence who once tried to market a piece of his lab equipment as something that could inform women if their silicone breast implants were leaking. At Balco, he sold a legal supplement called ZMA, which over time, the authors say, became a front for his real business: peddling performance-enhancing cocktails of anabolic steroids and human growth hormone, sometimes mixed with such compounds as insulin and the women's fertility drug Clomid. The drug regimens were complicated but devastatingly effective. 
 One client, Tim Montgomery, an undersize sprinter nicknamed Tiny Tim, told Conte that if he could win a gold medal, ''it would not matter if I died on the other side of the finish line.'' With Balco's drugs, the book says, he gained 28 pounds of muscle in just eight weeks. Later, he broke the world record in the 100-meter dash. 
 No one will read this book and come away wondering if steroids really work. Oh, they work. They bump a competitor up a whole pay grade -- from finishing in the middle of the pack in the final heat to breaking the tape and collecting the winner's bonus. 
 Jeff Pearlman, the author of ''Love Me, Hate Me,'' cedes the hard investigative terrain to ''Game of Shadows'' -- probably a necessary move, since the duo from The Chronicle own their story the way Woodward and Bernstein owned Watergate. What Pearlman leaves himself with is 300-plus pages to plumb the personality of Barry Bonds, which in its low range is bullying and abusive, and in its high range, sarcastic and self-pitying. 
 Pearlman, whose previous book was about the 1986 Mets, tracks down Bonds's former teachers, scout leaders, neighbors and teammates from Little League up through the majors -- more than 500 people total. The legwork is impressive, but nearly everyone says a version of the same thing -- that Bonds is a thoroughly miserable guy. The kind of person who throws sweat socks on the floor just to watch the clubhouse attendant stoop to pick them up. 
 ''Love Me, Hate Me'' (a more apt title would have been ''Hate Me, Hate Me'') does have one newsbreak -- comments attributed to Bonds while he and several others were dining after the 1998 season at the home of Ken Griffey Jr., now a star with the Cincinnati Reds. Bonds expresses frustration that players are taking steroids, and says: ''I'm just gonna start using some hard-core stuff and hopefully it won't hurt my body. Then I'll get out of the game and be done with it.'' 
 Griffey (predictably) says he doesn't remember the conversation, and Bonds (predictably) would not comment. Bonds did tell Pearlman, in their one brief encounter, that he'd never been in the Cub Scouts -- even after the reporter had interviewed the den mother of his troop. Whatever, dude. 
 After ''Game of Shadows'' was excerpted in Sports Illustrated in March, Commissioner Bud Selig announced thatformer Senator George Mitchell would lead an investigation to get to the bottom of what is now commonly referred to as baseball's ''steroid era.'' Good idea. 
 But what baseball needs more than an investigator is an ethicist, someone who will help us know what to make of all this. If Bonds took performance enhancers because he believed his competition was doing the same -- at a time when baseball was winking at, if not outright encouraging, the practice in the pursuit of home runs and ticket sales -- it would have been, on his part, a considered and rational act. A business decision, like the one baseball was making.
 Should his records be erased? And what of the records set during the whole era, when untold numbers of players did the same thing -- including almost certainly some whom we would be shocked to learn about?

HEADLINE: Money Changes Everything

BYLINE: By JENNIE YABROFF

 BODY:
GRETA GILBERTSON was caught off guard recently when her 9-year-old daughter, who attends a private school on the Upper West Side, requested a cellphone. 
 ''I sort of snapped at her,'' recalled Ms. Gilbertson, an assistant professor at Fordham University in the Bronx. ''I said, 'Don't think that you're one of the rich kids, because you're not.' '' Though her daughter rarely expresses envy of her more affluent friends, Ms. Gilbertson said, it was an ''unedited moment'' revealing her anxiety over being in a world where other parents have more money than she does.
Carol Paik, a former lawyer who is married to a partner at a prominent New York law firm, found herself on the other side of that money equation. When she returned to school in 2002 to get her M.F.A. in creative writing at Columbia, her diamond engagement ring attracted particular attention from her new group of friends. ''When I was working,'' she said, ''I never thought about the ring, it seemed unremarkable.'' 
 But at school, she said, ''People said things like, 'That's a really big diamond,' and not necessarily in a complimentary way.'' So she began taking off the ring before class. 
 If, as Samuel Butler said, friendships are like money, easier made than kept, economic differences can add yet another obstacle to maintaining them. More friends and acquaintances are now finding themselves at different points on the financial spectrum, scholars and sociologists say, thanks to broad social changes like meritocracy-based higher education, diversity in the workplace and a disparity of incomes among professions. 
 As people with various-sized bank accounts brush up against each other, there is ample cause for social awkwardness, which can strain relationships, sometimes to a breaking point. Many find themselves wrestling with complicated feelings about money and self-worth and improvising coping strategies.
 ''The real issue is not money itself, but the power money gives you,'' said Dalton Conley, a professor of sociology and the director of the Center for Advanced Social Science Research at New York University, who studies issues of wealth and class. ''Money makes explicit the inequalities in a relationship, so we work hard to minimize it as a form of tact.''
 For Ms. Gilbertson, that means not having her daughters' friends over to play because, she said, her apartment in Washington Heights is small and in what some parents might consider a marginal neighborhood. For the same reason, she had a pizza party for her daughter's birthday at the local Y.M.C.A. 
 For Ms. Paik, that meant avoiding inviting her classmates to her prewar, three-bedroom co-op on the Upper West Side, because many of them lived in student housing and she feared they would think she was showing off. ''I didn't want to introduce that barrier,'' she said.
 Money's discomfiting effects are explored in the recent film ''Friends with Money,'' in which three of four female friends are well off while one is barely getting by. In an early scene the friends are gathered for dinner when Olivia, a former schoolteacher played by Jennifer Aniston, announces that she has started working as a maid. A few moments later Franny, played by Joan Cusack, says she and her husband will be making a $2 million donation to their child's elementary school. When another friend asks why Franny doesn't just give the money to Olivia, everyone laughs uncomfortably and the subject is changed.
 ''Money is talked about with such discomfort; it's so taboo,'' said Nicole Holofcener, the writer and director of ''Friends With Money.'' ''With close friends it takes work; I have to make a conscious effort to talk about issues of money that come up between us.''
 Economic barriers to friendship have come about in part because other barriers have been broken down, sociologists say. College, where people form some of the most intense friendships of their lives, is a melting pot of economic differences. Students from country-club families and those on scholarships are thrown together as roommates, on athletic teams and in classes.
 ''There has been an incredible expansion of higher education,'' Professor Conley said. ''More people from more varied backgrounds are going to college. There are also more meritocratic admissions among elite institutions.'' 
 According to data compiled by Thomas Mortenson, a senior scholar at the Pell Institute in Washington, 42 percent of young adults (age 18 to 24) from the bottom quarter of family income were enrolled in college in 2003, compared with 28 percent in 1970. Enrollment for students from the two middle income quarters also increased. Participation of students from the highest-income families changed the least, with 80 percent attending college in 2003, compared with 74 percent in 1970.
 Once college friends leave campus, their economic status can diverge widely depending on their careers. While 20 years ago a young lawyer and a new college instructor might have commiserated about their jobs over coffee and doughnuts, today the lawyer would be able to invite the assistant professor out for a meal at a restaurant with two sommeliers and a cheese expert. 
 At New York University, for instance, instructors make $35,300 for the current academic year, up from $24,500 for the 1985-86 academic year, according to the American Association of University Professors. A first-year associate at a large New York law firm, however, can earn as much as $170,000 with a year-end bonus, compared with about $53,000, including bonus, in 1985. 
 ''In New York City we're on the front lines of the rise in inequality in income because it's happening at the top half of the income distribution ladder,'' Professor Conley said. ''The difference between the middle and the top has grown incredibly.''
 Although the wealthy can wall themselves off in buildings with doormen or in high-tax suburbs, other trends in society lead the affluent to brush up against the not-so-affluent. Gentrification, an urban movement from Prospect Heights, Brooklyn to downtown Los Angeles, moves the professional class into the neighborhoods of the working class. They mix when their children attend the same school or participate in athletic leagues. 
 Feeling awkward about the differences in net worth is not just an issue for those on the bottom of the equation. Some wealthy people -- especially the young -- have trouble admitting that they are different. 
 ''We are allegedly a classless society, and that's obviously completely untrue, but people don't want to acknowledge that those differences exist,'' said Jamie Johnson, a 26-year-old heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune. He explored attitudes about money among his peers in his 2003 documentary, ''Born Rich.'' His new documentary, ''The One Percent,'' which debuted at the Tribeca Film Festival on April 29, looks at the political influence of wealthy Americans. 
 Mr. Johnson said that some of his moneyed friends act like they have fewer resources than they do, making a show of taking the subway and saying they can't afford a cab. ''It's to avoid that awkwardness of seeing the distinction of social class,'' he said. 
 The pressure to fit in economically can be especially intense for teenagers and young adults. Marisa Gordon, a 27-year-old account executive at a midsize Manhattan advertising agency, recalled that as a student at Syracuse University, her roommate resented that Ms. Gordon had more spending money than she did. The roommate made comments when Ms. Gordon brought home a pair of Diesel sweatpants and cried because she couldn't afford the same Issey Miyake perfume. 
 Though she and the roommate are still friendly, Ms. Gordon said money issues contributed to the fact they aren't as close as they once were. Now it is her younger sister, a freshman at Syracuse, who is feeling the sort of competitive pressure Ms. Gordon's roommate felt. The sister recently asked their parents for a Louis Vuitton bag, Ms. Gordon said, because, ''Everyone at school has a Louis bag.'' 
 Suze Orman, a financial writer and speaker whose latest book is ''The Money Book for the Young, Fabulous and Broke'' (Riverhead Hardcover), said young adults can go into debt trying to keep up with their friends. 
 ''I call them 'money pods,' '' she said. ''Look at a group of female friends walking down the street. They're often all dressed identically: the same shoes, the same belts, the same handbag.'' 
 But what is not easily apparent, Ms. Orman said, is that one of the women may have saved for months to buy her one expensive handbag, or more likely, put it on her credit card. Her identically dressed friends, meanwhile, may have the salary or the family money to afford a closet full of designer purses. 
 ''That is how we get in trouble,'' Ms. Orman said. ''We think our friends are just like us, and if our friend can afford something, we fool ourselves into thinking we can afford it, too.'' 
 Mary Ochsner, a stay-at-home mother of three in San Clemente, Calif., ended a friendship after money issues came to the fore. She had befriended a woman after college when they were both, as she put it, in ''very affluent periods.'' But their paths diverged when Ms. Ochsner married a Marine and her friend married a man whom Ms. Ochsner described as an ambitious executive. She said her friend became increasingly status-conscious and would brag about home improvements. 
 The final insult came, Ms. Ochsner said, when she invited the woman to a birthday party for her daughter. The woman barely socialized but tried to poach her babysitter by offering $5 more an hour than what Ms. Ochsner was paying. Ms. Ochsner decided the friendship wasn't worth it. 
 ''It wasn't about the money,'' she said. ''The money made me realize she had different social ambitions.'' 
 Perhaps the most fraught social ritual of all when it comes to money and friendship is the settling of a restaurant bill. ''I know wealthy people who are extremely troubled by the whole idea of who's going to pay the bill,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''They're terrified for hours before it happens.'' 
 He said he has found himself arguing over the check with a dining companion who was not as wealthy. ''Sometimes people feel obligated to buy me dinner because they don't want me to think I'm expected to pay for the meal,'' he said. ''I don't really appreciate it. If anything, I think it's unfortunate that people feel that uncertainty.'' 
 The uneasiness is also acute on the other side of the income divide. A 30-year-old book editor in Manhattan who earns less than $40,000 a year recently went to Miami for the weekend with two friends from high school who both work for hedge funds.
 ''We're staying at the Shore Club, in a suite they've booked; I'm sleeping on the pullout couch and they're paying for it, which is hugely generous of them,'' the editor wrote in an e-mail message. He has not been identified to avoid offending his friends. ''However, tonight they've booked a table at Nobu, with Mansion'' -- an expensive night club -- ''to follow. I'll end up spending about a week's pay in the next two nights, probably more. It'll feel worth it while I'm hanging out with them without any of the unpleasant reminders that our lives have seriously diverged since high school, but it's going to sting when I get back.'' 
 Mike Seely, a 31-year-old journalist in Seattle, recently arranged a lunch date with a wealthier friend who works in politics. He said he suggested a diner ''where nothing's over $10, right in my price range.'' She countered by suggesting the Dahlia Lounge, an upscale restaurant where a spinach salad costs $14. 
 ''I said, 'Sure, as long as this is on your dime,' '' he said. 
 It was one of the few times he has felt comfortable addressing the issue so directly, he said, because his friend was the one to press for the more expensive place. 
 Even those who study the topic for a living have a hard time when it comes to divvying up the check. ''I have friends who are economists who are comfortable getting down to the last decimal point of who owes what when we go out,'' Professor Conley said. Yet he feels compelled to keep quiet when he finds himself across the table from a friend who orders three glasses of wine to his tap water, then suggests they split the tab. 
 ''It's probably because I don't want to appear petty,'' he explained. ''I'd be battling pretty strong social norms.''

HEADLINE: A Message Aimed at Big Oil, or Pain for the Little Guy?

BYLINE: By DAVID STABA

 BODY:
Kathleen C. Hochul wanted to send Big Oil a message. 
 She had heard the recent news from Bee County, Tex., where the county commissioners passed a resolution calling for a boycott of Exxon Mobil to protest high gas prices, the company's record $36.1 billion profit in 2005, and its chairman's $400 million retirement deal.
So last Monday, Ms. Hochul, a member of the Hamburg Town Council, introduced her own resolution. It called on residents to boycott the town's five Exxon Mobil stations and on Hamburg municipal employees to avoid filling up any of the 175 town vehicles with Exxon gas. 
 ''We heard what they were doing in Texas and we took it another step,'' Ms. Hochul said. ''Our motive was really to draw attention to what we consider a crisis situation.'' 
 The resolution was passed unanimously by the bipartisan council. But some of the attention it has drawn in Hamburg, a town of 56,000 people about 5 miles south of Buffalo, was not quite what Ms. Hochul or other board members expected.
 She did receive calls of support from residents fed up with steadily rising prices. But she also got calls from people who complained that the town was unfairly picking on the local gas stations. Four of them are owned by local business people and the fifth is owned by a chain. 
 ''It kind of irks me,'' said Joseph J. Enser, who owns one of the independent stations affiliated with Exxon Mobil. ''All these years I've been paying taxes on my business, and now they want people to boycott me. If they put me out of business, who is going to make up for the taxes they'll lose?''
 Mr. Enser opened a Shell station in 1971, selling regular gas for 29.9 cents per gallon, he said. He has sold gas under the banner of most major oil companies, including Amoco, Pennzoil, Citgo and BP. He has been selling Exxon gas for more than three years.
 ''It's not going to help solve the problem,'' Mr. Enser said of a boycott. ''All it's doing is hurting small businesses. Exxon is still going to sell all the supply it wants.''
 Mr. Enser said he made between four and six cents per gallon sold. He made roughly 10 cents per gallon 35 years ago, adjusting for inflation, allowing him a much larger rate of profit than he receives now.
 Some residents said their loyalties were with the local stations rather than the supplier.
 ''This is more of a convenience,'' Phil Dutson, a salesman who said he spent about $100 a week on gas, said while filling up one afternoon last week at an Exxon Mobil station around the corner from his house. ''It's right here, and you get to know the people who work here.''
 An Exxon Mobil spokeswoman said that making a target of the corporation was misguided.
 ''Exxon Mobil does not and could not control the market price of gasoline,'' Premlata Nair said in an e-mail message. ''There are many factors that impact gas prices, and the biggest influence continues to be demand and supply for crude oil and petroleum products and local supply and demand for gasoline.''
 On Friday, Ms. Hochul and other town officials met with the station owners, including Mr. Enser. Afterward, Ms. Hochul said she would move to rescind the boycott at Monday's town board meeting and replace it with one encouraging conservation and calling on state and federal officials to roll back gas taxes.
 ''The town has acknowledged that these are not the people we're looking to target,'' Ms. Hochul said on Friday.
 But Mr. Enser, who complained that he had been portrayed as a ''gouger,'' said: ''The damage to the businesses in Hamburg can't be undone. But it's a start toward healing the wounds.'' 
 Ms. Hochul said she did not regret the boycott.
 ''In our small way, we wanted to say, 'We can't take it any more,' '' she said. ''But we don't want to continue the boycott at the expense of these hard-working business people in our town.''

HEADLINE: This Pause May Have To Wait

BYLINE: By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
BEN S. BERNANKE has suggested that the Federal Reserve may skip a chance to raise interest rates at some point soon, but one investment adviser cautioned against expecting that pause when Fed policy makers meet on Wednesday. 
 ''There is a near certainty we'll see 5 percent'' in the Fed's benchmark short-term interest rate, said John K. Lynch, chief market analyst at Evergreen Investments; the rate currently is 4.75 percent. After that, he said, ''they could pause, but I don't know how they'll telegraph that; I don't think they'll say, 'We're done.' ''
Instead, Mr. Lynch said, ''they'll probably provide a nebulous comment'' reiterating that future action will depend on new economic data. ''I think they'll string us along for another six weeks,'' he predicted. 
 Mr. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, has good reason to resort to the same Delphic ambiguity for which his predecessor, Alan Greenspan, was renowned. The economy itself is sending mixed signals, Mr. Lynch said.
 Although inflation is not severe at the moment, it may flare up and spread through the economy too quickly and widely for the Fed to control it, Mr. Lynch said. ''Energy costs have not seeped into other goods and services,'' he said, ''but if the Fed pauses with faster global growth and the weaker dollar and high prices for oil and gold, they run the risk of getting behind.'' He added: ''The risks are remote at this point, but I don't think they're going to paint themselves into a corner. There are a lot of issues they've got to factor in.'' 
 Stocks may sell off without a more concrete statement from the Fed, he warned, but the mercurial spirit of traders should help to ensure a swift recovery.
 ''They may be disappointed, but if they are, there will be a 24-hour mourning period, then they'll be on to something else,'' Mr. Lynch said.

DATA WATCH -- The size of the gulf between the nation's imports and exports in March will be announced on Friday. A Bloomberg News poll of economists forecasts a deficit of $66.8 billion, bigger than the $65.7 billion in February.
 That report often carries weight with traders, but it may be viewed as old news this time around. The dollar has fallen about 5 percent since the end of March, making foreign goods that much cheaper for American shoppers and cutting the prices of products made here for buyers abroad. That should reduce the deficit in coming months, at least in theory.


CORRECTION-DATE: May 21, 2006

 CORRECTION:
The Market Week column on May 7 misstated the effect of a weakening dollar on the price of imports. They tend to become more expensive for American shoppers, not cheaper.

HEADLINE: Magic Man

BYLINE: By TED WIDMER. 
Ted Widmer is the director of the C. V. Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience at Washington College.

 BODY:
THE DEFINING MOMENT
 FDR's Hundred Days and
 the Triumph of Hope.
 By Jonathan Alter.
 Illustrated. 414 pp. Simon & Schuster. $29.95.
Lately Franklin D. Roosevelt has seemed strangely vulnerable, and not merely because of our new inclination to memorialize him in his wheelchair. The percentage of Americans who can truly remember him is small and dwindling. A few years ago, House Republicans tried to remove his profile from the dime and replace him with Ronald Reagan. Meanwhile, a recent spate of books from the right, including Jim Powell's ''FDR's Folly'' and Thomas E. Woods Jr.'s ''Politically Incorrect Guide to American History,'' have accused him of prolonging the Great Depression and generally screwing up America. 
 But memory of the New Deal has not entirely flickered out, thanks to a flurry of literary activity on the other side, including recent pro-Roosevelt books by academics (Cass Sunstein, Alonzo L. Hamby) and, surprisingly, a conservative press lord (Conrad Black). Their ranks are now joined by a new defender: Jonathan Alter, a senior editor at Newsweek. Since writing a paper on the 32nd president when he was 11, Alter has nurtured a schoolboy crush on F.D.R., chatting about the New Deal with politicians (the acknowledgments thank Presidents Ford and Clinton) and digging through assorted archives. The result is a most readable book -- not quite a biography or a detailed policy study, but a reflection on the way that Roosevelt reinvented the presidency during his first hundred days in office, through bold policy innovations, brilliant speeches and broadcasts and a personal connection with the American people that has not been equaled since. 
 Alter shrewdly reads this achievement as a matter of style as much as substance, and spends considerable time examining the subtle ways in which F.D.R. embodied hope to a people consumed by despair. He gives much of the credit for this ineffable confidence to Roosevelt's earlier struggle with a disability that relatively few Americans were aware he had. Through his agonizing triumph over polio and the bond he discovered with fellow sufferers, Alter writes, Roosevelt discovered ''traits that would prove instrumental to the presidency'' -- a theatrical bonhomie, mental suppleness and an empathy for the downtrodden that had not characterized his early career.
 The book begins in the dark days of March 1933, with a vivid depiction of an American financial system close to collapse. Stocks were down 75 percent in four years. Exports were at their lowest level since 1904. Banks were shuttered around the country, and unemployment in some cities had reached 80 percent. Alter reminds readers that Roosevelt came close to not even making it to this unenviable rendezvous with destiny -- an assassination attempt in Miami two weeks earlier almost ended the New Deal before it even began.
 But with a great actor's sense of instinct, Roosevelt rose to the occasion, converting all of these tensions into what Alter calls ''an exquisite piece of political theater.'' Through his words, his improvisations and his effortless optimism, Roosevelt resuscitated American capitalism, and in so doing, may have saved democracy as well. The new president was fortunate in his predecessor, the dour Herbert Hoover. (In reality, Alter reminds us that some of the New Deal's earliest successes, including the rescue of the banks, stemmed from ideas offered by departing Hoover officials.) But of course there was more to F.D.R.'s magic than the mere fact that he was less depressing than a man whose name had become synonymous with slums around the country. Alter illuminates how Roosevelt made the presidency exciting and responsive and alive. Fifty staffers were needed to handle the mail sent to the Roosevelt White House; under Hoover, this job had belonged to a single employee. 
 ''The Defining Moment'' is not without its shortcomings. Some of the chapters are very short, almost sidebars, and the presidency does not even begin until halfway through the book. Footnotes frequently make labored comparisons with the present, for example an effort to link a Roosevelt spelling mistake with Dan Quayle's famous stab at ''potato.'' At one point, Alter argues that much as Bill Clinton could be said to be the first black president, Roosevelt may have been ''the first woman president,'' because of his sympathy for women's rights and ''an intuition rarely found in male leaders.''
 And then there's Alter's discussion of an ''eye popping'' sentence in a draft of the first radio speech of Roosevelt's presidency, which would have had him saying to a gathering of veterans: ''As new commander in chief under the oath to which you are still bound I reserve to myself the right to command you in any phase of the situation which now confronts us.'' This, Alter writes, was ''dictator talk,'' ''an explicit power grab'' that echoed Mussolini and ''every other crisis leader in world history.'' But Alter's emphasis on this point feels like a stretch, mainly because Roosevelt never delivered this version of the speech. 
 Still, Alter's account has a refreshing buoyancy, not unlike its protagonist. Near the end of the book, Alter allows at least one unflattering comparison with the current White House into his text, but he is a fair reporter, describing Roosevelt's missteps (like his opposition to federal deposit insurance) as honestly as his triumphs. Alter's book will not replace the classic study of the early New Deal written by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., but it succeeds in bringing a remarkable man back to life. 
 In fact, if there is an overarching frustration to the experience of reading this book, it is that the panorama of hope and ingenuity that Alter paints for us today seems a thing of the past.
