HEADLINE: A Resurgence in the Bronx Is Finally Putting the Grand Back in the Concourse

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

 BODY:
During one of the Grand Concourse's low points, in the 1960's, the city's Parks Department decided not to replant grass in the boulevard's median. Instead, it poured cement and painted it green.
 It was an indignity for a street that had once been the Bronx's most prestigious address -- a Park Avenue at middle-class prices. 
At 4.5 miles, the Grand Concourse is neither the Bronx's longest street, nor its busiest, but since it was completed 97 years ago, it has been a barometer of the borough's economic vitality -- its successes and failures reflected in the fading mosaics and fresh graffiti painted on the six-story Art Deco and Art Moderne apartment houses that line it.
 Now, as it approaches its centennial in 2009, the Grand Concourse is at the center of a flurry of activity correlating with the Bronx's economic resurgence, including an $18 million project to rebuild the Concourse near Yankee Stadium; an $8.2 million expansion of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, scheduled to be finished in October; and a city program that offers low-interest loans for the rehabilitation of some prewar rental buildings.
 The projects include the redesign of Lou Gehrig Plaza -- between the Grand Concourse and Yankee Stadium -- which is being used as a parking lot for the Bronx County Courthouse but will be transformed into a formal plaza and terraced park. The Concourse itself will get new trees, flowers, streetlights, bike lanes and cobblestone sidewalks. Within a few blocks of the boulevard, a $325 million glass and aluminum criminal courthouse is nearing completion, and a new $800 million stadium for the Yankees is scheduled to open in 2009.
 ''To Bronxites, the Grand Concourse has always been the elegant boulevard,'' said Lloyd Ultan, the Bronx borough historian. ''As a showcase, as a symbol, it stood a lot for what the Bronx is and was.''
 The Grand Concourse starts its gently winding path north at 138th Street in the South Bronx and ends just short of Van Cortlandt Park at Mosholu Parkway in the northern part of the borough. Officially the Grand Boulevard and Concourse, it was conceived by a French civil engineer and modeled after the Champs-Elysees in Paris as a scenic path for the wealthy to get from Manhattan to the large parks of the Bronx.
 The northern portion, from 161st Street, was completed in 1909, while Mott Avenue was renamed and became the southern section of the concourse in 1927.
 After the subway under the Concourse opened, in 1933, developers rushed to build apartments along the street. Almost all of them were five or six stories tall. Building any higher required fireproof construction, which was more expensive.
 To lure tenants north from the Lower East Side and other parts of Manhattan, builders included grand lobbies, courtyards, elevators and sunken living rooms, and sufficient windows to provide sunlight and cross-ventilation -- features relatively foreign to the tenements from which many of the new tenants were drawn.
 An address on the Grand Concourse became a mark of social status. Among the street's residents from the its glory days, from the 1930's to the early 1960's, were Stanley Kubrick, Roberta Peters, Milton Berle, Penny Marshall and E. L. Doctorow.
 But the Concourse was not immune once the Bronx began its economic slide in the 1960's. Urban-renewal projects forced many poor black and Puerto Rican New Yorkers from their neighborhoods to the South Bronx. The ethnic shift led to fear among the Concourse's longtime residents, an angst that some said was whipped up by politicians and real estate speculators. Within a few years, many of those residents moved away, drawn to Riverdale and to the vast new Co-op City.
 ''The street was very vulnerable to any kind of change, because everybody came here at the same time,'' said Sam Goodman, an urban planner in the Bronx borough president's office, who has lived on the Grand Concourse since he was a child.
 Like most of the South Bronx, the Grand Concourse -- particularly the section south of Fordham Road -- was threatened by arson, crime and neglect throughout the 1980's. But unlike much of the South Bronx, not a single apartment building along the street was destroyed. And because no buildings burned down, the boulevard avoided large rebuilding projects that would have changed its character. As a result, the street looks much the same as it did 50 or 60 years ago.
 Some buildings, however, never recovered from neglect and eventual abandonment. The Concourse Plaza Hotel, built in the 1920's, whose guests included President Harry S. Truman and Yankee stars from Babe Ruth to Billy Martin, became a home for welfare families in the 1960's. Its deteriorating grandeur led John Cassavetes to shoot scenes there for the 1980 film ''Gloria'' that needed gloomy interiors. Eventually, the hotel, including its grand ballroom, was gutted, and it is now a home for the elderly. 
 The Andrew J. Freedman Home, a block-long Italianate Renaissance mansion built at 166th Street by a former owner of the New York Giants baseball team, opened in 1924 as a home for the formerly wealthy who had suffered reverses. Today, the future of the building, owned by the Mid-Bronx Senior Citizens Council, a nonprofit group, is in doubt. Only the basement of the four-story building is in use, by a variety of social service providers.
 Many other buildings along the street, however, appear to be in the midst of their own rebirths. Executive Towers, a 24-story co-op building with uniformed doormen, built in the 1960's, has gone from near insolvency and just one-third occupancy in the late 1980's to offering one-bedroom apartments for $180,000 today.
 Two years ago, Lukas Herbert, an urban planner who works for Westchester County, bought a one-bedroom apartment in Executive Towers for $65,000.
 ''I'm pretty much expecting the neighborhood to continue to improve,'' said Mr. Herbert. ''I don't know why it wouldn't. The building stock is amazing.''

HEADLINE: At Trial on Subway Bomb Plot, Informer Finishes Star Turn

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

 BODY:
At midday yesterday, a paid police informer, the key witness against a young Pakistani immigrant charged with plotting to blow up the Herald Square subway station, ended eight days on the witness stand.
 It was an unusually long stretch for any witness in a criminal trial, and it had clearly left him ragged.
But it was also an unusual performance, one in which the informer, Osama Eldawoody, 50, seemed both numbingly obsequious and frustratingly recalcitrant. 
 Even the assistant United States attorney who called him as a witness sometimes looked impatient, particularly when Mr. Eldawoody wandered off on tangents, occasionally turning to address the jury directly as he spoke of the more than a dozen recordings he had secretly made of the bomb plot.
 Mr. Eldawoody's performance could have a significant impact on the outcome of the trial in United States District Court in Brooklyn. His credibility is at the heart of the government's case, because defense lawyers have argued that he entrapped their client, Shahawar Matin Siraj, 23, and was himself the driving force behind the plot.
 The jurors appeared frustrated at times with Mr. Eldawoody.
 A slightly built man with tousled, jet-black hair, he was prone to fidgeting on the stand. He often gestured with a white ballpoint pen, sometimes wagging it back and forth like an admonishing finger, sometimes stabbing it in the air for emphasis. He spoke often in disjointed phrases.
 During nearly four days of cross-examination last week, the panel listened for hours as he gave the same answers over and over again.
 ''Possible,'' he said in response to scores of questions.
 ''Very possible'' was his reply to scores of others.
 He would often end his answers with a seemingly incongruous ''Thank you.''
 Yesterday, on at least two occasions, Mr. Eldawoody seemed almost to rebuke Mr. Siraj's lawyer, Martin J. Stolar, with the lawyer-like complaint that the question contained two separate inquiries.
 ''These are two different points,'' Mr. Eldawoody replied when Mr. Stolar asked whether he had told the defendant that he might have liver cancer and stomach cancer.

Bombs, Marriage, 'Pizza'
 The first week of Mr. Eldawoody's testimony was largely dominated by the young defendant's own sometimes giddy, high-pitched voice.
 The jury heard hour after hour of recordings of Mr. Siraj's conversations with the informer, who in effect annotated the tapes for the prosecution from the witness stand.
 At a few points on the recordings, Mr. Eldawoody, an Egyptian-born nuclear engineer, sounds almost fatherly, taking a gentle tone. He can be heard offering Mr. Siraj guidance not only on bombs and nuclear weapons but also on marriage.
 Mr. Siraj seems at times obsessed with the idea of obtaining nuclear weapons, although he emphasizes to the informer that he wants to carry out attacks that will cause only economic damage, killing as few people as possible.
 He also says he doesn't want to make a martyr of himself, because he wants to be able to keep carrying out attacks.
 On one recording, Mr. Eldawoody makes a half-hearted attempt to explain to Mr. Siraj -- whose own lawyer has described him as ''not the brightest bulb on the chandelier'' -- the difference between neutron and biological weapons. On another, Mr. Siraj asks whether atomic weapons and nuclear weapons are the same.
 On the recordings, Mr. Siraj seems occasionally to be entranced by his own view of a terrorist's tradecraft.
 At one point, he tries to explain to the older man how they can alert their confederates that a bomb has been placed in the subway. ''You have to call the brother, 'Hello, brother, I did my job, that's it, I deliver the pizza, O.K.? I deliver the pizza, O.K.' ''

Defendant's Demeanor
 While Mr. Siraj often sounds animated on the tapes, his demeanor in court during the first week was subdued and stoical.
 He seldom looked at the witness or at the jury. Seated between two of his three lawyers, he occasionally whispered to one or the other.
 Several times he looked into the courthouse gallery, where his grandparents and his father sat almost every day, sometimes accompanied by his uncle, who owns the Islamic bookstore where he worked. His mother waited in the hallway outside the courtroom, because she is expected to be called as a defense witness and cannot therefore listen to the proceedings.
 But his expression has changed little.
 He spent most of the first week of testimony hunched over a legal pad, scribbling or doodling with his face barely six inches from the page.
 During the cross-examination of Mr. Eldawoody, he became more animated, following in a book of transcripts as his lawyer played several tapes.
 His appearance changed dramatically in the middle of last week, however, after prosecutors played in court a secretly recorded videotape in which he was heard discussing the bomb plot.
 The warden at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, where Mr. Siraj is being held, ordered him into solitary confinement for his own protection, out of what he said was concern for his safety, according to Mr. Stolar. For two days, the young man appeared haggard and unshaven before the jury, wearing trousers and a sweater instead of his previous suit and open-collared shirt.
 Mr. Stolar said the warden had eventually been convinced that it would be safe to return Mr. Siraj to general population, and yesterday the defendant appeared rested and clean-shaven and was back in his suit.

HEADLINE: Rents to Rise At Least 3%, And Tenants Howl in Anger

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT

 BODY:
The board that sets rents for the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City proposed tentative increases last night of 3 to 6.5 percent on one-year leases and 5 to 8.5 percent on two-year leases, setting the stage for increases that are likely to be larger than last year's when the board holds a final vote next month.
 Last night's vote by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, in a raucous meeting in which hooting and bellowing tenants often drowned out the proceedings, came on the heels of a recent board report that apartment owners' costs had risen by 7.8 percent in the last year, driven by a 22.8 percent rise in fuel costs and a jump in real estate taxes. 
The vote was 5 to 4, with the board's two tenant members and two owner members voting against the proposal and its five other members in favor of it. Marvin Markus, the board chairman, who made the proposal, said last month that it would be a ''serious challenge'' to hold this year's increases to last year's levels of 2.75 and 5.5 percent, respectively, for one- and two-year leases.
 The proposed rent rise comes at a time when real wages, or earnings adjusted for inflation, have fallen in every borough but Manhattan, according to federal statistics released this year. At the same time, landlords have insisted that past rent increases have not kept up with costs, giving some owners no choice but to sell to speculators.
 ''I see two New Yorks,'' Adriene Holder, a tenant board member, said at the hearing. ''I see one increasingly affluent. And I see another one increasingly, increasingly becoming more poor.'' She added, ''Landlords are hardly impoverished, landlords are hardly hurting, landlords are hardly poor.''
 But Steven J. Schleider, an owner member, said the ranges recommended last night were too low and failed to recognize what he said was a cumulative increase in operating costs of 31 percent over the past three years. In an interview after the vote, he said, ''It sends a signal to landlords of barely profitable apartment buildings that it's time to get out.''
 The board will hold two public hearings and a public meeting on the proposal next month, then will hold a final vote on June 27, settling on specific guidelines, not a range. In the past, the board's final votes have not deviated sharply from its preliminary ones. In theory, the board has the right to vote above or below the proposed range.
 The meeting last night, in an auditorium at Cooper Union, proceeded with all the orderliness and calm of a British soccer match or a Roman gladiators' fight. Tenants marched, chanting, outside the building; then several hundred filled the hall and shouted down the speakers, insulted the board members, chanted, drummed and hooted.
 At one point, a woman rose from her seat and began a lengthy monologue about her own housing troubles, cheered on by the audience. When she made her way, still talking, to the floor in front of the stage, where she was immediately engulfed by television cameras, Mr. Markus briefly adjourned the meeting and walked off the stage.
 After the board returned, the tenant board members proposed a one-year rent freeze, which the board voted down, 7 to 2. Next, the owner members made their own proposal for a 7 percent increase on one-year leases and a 7 percent increase on the first year of two-year leases, with the second year's increase to be determined next year. As an alternative, they proposed a 6 percent increase on one-year leases and 9 percent for two-year leases.
 Their proposal, too, failed 7 to 2.
 The proposal that finally passed applies to rent-stabilized apartments and lofts. The board also voted 5 to 4 in favor of a proposal for increases of up to 2 percent for rent-stabilized hotels, like residential hotels, rooming houses and single-room-occupancy hotels.
 The board rejected a motion by Ms. Holder to deny rent increases to owners of buildings in which at least a quarter of all the units are no longer rent-stabilized -- instances in which the owners collect market rents from a significant number of tenants -- as well as to owners with serious outstanding building code violations.
 Mr. Markus said the city's corporation counsel had prepared a 10-page memo that said Ms. Holder's proposal was ''not consistent with the powers of the Rent Guidelines Board.''
 Jumaane D. Williams, the executive director of Tenants and Neighbors, a statewide tenants organization, objected later in an interview not only to the size of the proposed increases, but also to Mr. Markus's use of ranges instead of specific percentages, which he and others complained makes the proposals more difficult to oppose.
